summary: This document is an email chain from May 2020 between U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) prosecutors and FBI personnel discussing logistical challenges and delays in processing and transferring digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's residences in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands. The emails focus on obtaining a complete inventory of seized devices, coordinating data transfer, and addressing technical problems with previously provided data.

connections.description: Implied colleagues within the FBI or related contractor team working on processing Epstein evidence.

events.title: Email coordination on evidence transfer
events.description: Email chain discussing plans to transfer raw data from seized devices, addressing logistical hurdles due to remote work.

events.title: Epstein residence searches
events.description: Search warrants executed at Epstein's New York mansion and U.S. Virgin Islands residence, resulting in seizure of numerous electronic devices.

events.title: Initial data transfer
events.description: Previous transfer of load files from seized devices to the U.S. Attorney's Office, referenced as having modified dates of 11/14/19.

events.title: Subsequent data transfer
events.description: Transfer of a large new folder ('NYC024362') containing over 600,000 items from the Epstein evidence.

keyFacts: The FBI seized approximately 40+ electronic devices from Epstein's New York mansion and 25+ devices from his U.S. Virgin Islands residence in August/September 2019.
Significant technical problems existed with previously transferred data: emails could not be linked to attachments, load files did not match native files, and many large files were inaccessible.
Processing of the seized evidence was severely delayed, with the U.S. Attorney's Office still seeking a complete inventory and raw data transfer eight months after the searches.
The volume of data was substantial, with one recent transfer alone containing over 600,000 items and total documents exceeding one million.
The correspondence reveals internal frustration with the FBI's evidence handling and discusses potentially outsourcing processing to external vendors like Kroll or BRG.
